The President of the ECB will comment on the considerations underlying these decisions at a press conference starting at 2.30 p.m. CET today. The European Central Bank decision is just a couple of minutes away. Over on CNBC, Danny Gabay of Fathom Consulting is arguing that the ECB should plunge into full-blown quantitative easing (even though it's far from clear that this could be allowed under its mandate) Meanwhile, one of the largest criminal trials ever held over the collapse of a financial institution continued in Dublin today, as three former Anglo Irish Bank executives appeared in court for the second day. From Dublin, Henry McDonald reports: The crisis that was engulfing Anglo Irish Bank in the year of the 2008 financial crash forced executives to hold an unprecedented 33 board meetings in that period, a Dublin court heard today. Natasha Mercer, a one time company secretary at the now defunct bank, told the trial of Anglo Irish bosses Sean Fitzpatrick, Patrick Whelan and Wiliam McAteer, that normally the bank held between 8 to 10 board meetings per annum. But such was the extent of the panic infected the bank that they were meeting on average more than twice a month in 2008, the court was told. Earlier the 15 strong jury was shown graphs on computer screens of how the shares in the bank were in "very clear decline" in 2008. On St Patrick’s Day of 2008, there was a significant drop in the price to €6.95. This coincided with the failure of Bear Stearns Bank, the court heard. But by the summer the price of a share in Anglo had fallen to €5.95. It went below €5 for the first time about July 10th. It went back up after July 17th and hovered around the €5-€6 mark during August. But by September 24th, the price had dropped to €3.98. It was at €2.03 on September 29th. The Anglo Irish trio are charged with providing unlawful financial assistance to 16 named individuals in 2008 - the year the bank was later rescued by the Irish and European taxpayers. Fitzpatrick, Whelan and McAteer pleaded not guilty to all the charges against them. Across the City, traders and economists are scampering for a quick sandwich or suchlike before the European Central Bank announces its own decision on monetary policy, in around 20 minutes (12.45pm GMT or 1.45pm Frankfurt time). Ilya Spivak, currency analyst at DailyFX, says the markets are in "chipper mood" ahead of the ECB's decision: The central bank is under pressure to deliver additional easing as disappointing CPI inflation data and sinking inflation expectations feed deflation fears and challenge the central bank’s mandate to maintain price stability. As flagged up earlier in the blog, the ECB has plenty of options -- including cutting interest rates, or imposing negative rates on bank deposits. Another option would be to copy the Bank of England's Funding for Lending scheme, to drive down credit costs in the euro area, Spivak added. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), says the Bank of England made the right call, and should now reshape its forward guidance on when interest rates might eventually rise: “Given the global uncertainties, and the still delicate state of the UK economy, the decision to hold both interest rates and QE was uncontroversial and appropriate. As British business has enjoyed the added stability and confidence that has come with the forward guidance policy, the speculation favouring an early interest rate rise is unhelpful and potentially damaging for the economy. “While the essence of the forward guidance strategy is to reassure businesses that interest rates will be kept as low as economic conditions will allow, the MPC should use next week’s Inflation Report to place its policy on firmer foundations. Linking forward guidance exclusively to unemployment has proved counter-productive. Focusing instead on a range of key indicators would increase its effectiveness, reinforce business confidence, and pour cold water on the cynicism that many city analysts have demonstrated. Here's some instant reaction to the Bank of England's no-change in interest rates, and no statement on monetary policy: The Bank of England has voted to leave UK interest rates at 0.5% -- maintaining borrowing costs at the record low set way back in March 2009. There's also no change to its quantitative easing programme, which remains at £375bn. And there's no statement -- hardly a surprise given we get the quarterly inflation report next week. Just five minutes until the Bank of England announces its monthly monetary policy decision..... European stock markets have rallied through the morning -- with lunchtime looming, the main indices are up at least 1%. Construction firm Vinci is leading the risers on the FTSEurofirst 100, after reporting better-than-expected results on Wednesday. It's being closely slip-streamed by Daimler (which raised its operating profit forecasts this morning) and Volvo (after announcing fresh job cuts) Albert Edwards, the famously bearish City analyst, and his team at SocGen have produced an interesting graph showing how corporate profits from the emerging market sector have recently now lagging behind the equivalent in developed economies. Another sign of a slowdown, or worse, in the EM world? The Dutch far-right leader, Geert Wilders, has raised the political temperature ahead of this spring's European parliament elections, by releasing a study showing the Netherlands' economy would grow faster if the country quit the EU. The FT has the story: Geert Wilders, leader of the far-right Freedom Party (PVV) that is leading in Dutch polls for May’s European parliament elections, presented a study on Thursday that claims the Netherlands would be better off if it left the EU and urged voters to support his call for “Nexit”. The study, by the consultancy Capital Economics, claims the Dutch economy would quickly emerge from its current sluggishness to brisk growth, generating billions of euros – or new Dutch guilders – in fresh revenues for debt-laden Dutch households. “Leaving the EU or Nexit will not only restore our national sovereignty but it will also boost the Dutch economy now and in the future,” Mr Wilders said in The Hague. “It also offers the Netherlands a way out of the crisis . . . Nexit will create jobs; the income of our citizens and companies will grow." The Netherlands finally left recession last autumn, but still faces wide-ranging austerity measures as the government tries to bring its deficit below the EU's 3% target. Carsten Brzeski of ING reckons that the 0.5% drop in German industrial orders in December is encouraging news: Here's his reasoning: German new orders have been on a zig-zag trend for almost two years. In this regards, today’s decline is actually good news. Why? Recently, strong monthly increases were always followed by strong declines the month after. Today’s small drop confirms the upward trend for the German industry. Order books are gradually filling. Combined with the low level of inventories, industrial production should gain more momentum in the coming months, hopefully closing the current wide gap between euphoric confidence indicators and rather sluggish hard data. Meanwhile in France, the president's popularity continues to hit new lows according to new polling today - with fewer than one in five people saying they support Francois Hollande. German manufacturing orders dropped unexpectedly in December, due to a slump in domestic demand. Germany Economy Ministry just reported that industrial orders fell 0.5% during the month, with domestic orders sliding 1.6% month-on-month. Foreign orders, though, rose 0.4% - thanks to a 7.5% surge in new business from the eurozone. So rather than Germany stimulating its neighbours' economies, it looks like the rest of the eurozone gave its largest member a lift in December. Or as the Economy Ministry put it: It is especially pleasing that the strongly rising orders from the euro zone signal the recovery continues apace. On a two-month basis (the less volatile measure), total new orders were up 1.1%. Speaking of banks, one of Northern Ireland's so-called 'pillar banks' (the victim of a huge robbery nearly a decade ago) has made a dramatic turnaround in its fortunes. Henry McDonald has the details: The Danske Bank made a pre-tax profit of £11.4 million in 2013, the company said. This compares to losses of more than £58 million in the previous year and is the first time since the financial crash of 2008 that the bank has gone into profit. The improved performance was driven by reduced bad loan charges alongside a better underlying business. Danske is one of the top three banks for customers in the region and used to be known as the Northern Bank. The one time locally owned bank was first taken over by an Australian bank and then by its current Danish owners. As the Northern Bank in 2004 its Belfast headquarters close to City Hall became the focal point of the biggest bank robbery in UK criminal history when the Provisional IRA staged a £26m heist. No one has ever been convicted in relation to the robbery, which almost killed off hopes of a peace deal between republicans and unionists. However the bank along with the other major financial institutions in Northern Ireland lost far more in the lending-spree that fuelled the property boom on both sides of the Irish border prior to the 2008 global crash. City analyst Louise Cooper points out that Mario Draghi may not be too alarmed by the current low inflation rates in Europe, given they are the product of austerity programme pushed, in part, by the ECB: Draghi and his contemporaries have wanted price falls in the periphery countries to “restore their competitiveness”. Because of strict rules prohibiting the ECB from monetising governments, the amount spent on the SMP has to be “sterilised” – the sum spent on SMP has to be withdrawn from the EZ system normally weekly. This is unlike in the UK and US where QE has injected trillions into the banking systems. Ending the liquidity drain would add almost €180bn to Euro system. That would be a big boost to money supply and could counteract deflation. Bloomberg reports that “The Bundesbank supports ending the liquidity absorption and has deliberated on the measure in the ECB’s monetary-policy and market-operations committees”. To end the liquidity drain on the SMP would be a big change for ECB policy (and could be challenged by the German constitutional court). Finance Ministry sources admitted on Wednesday that talks about extending the maturities on eurozone loans to 50 years had been “on the table for the past few months.” The admission came after Bloomberg reported that two people with knowledge of the discussions said the option was being debated. Twitter gave the markets a nasty surprise last night when it reported limited growth in new users and a drop in timeline views. Many of these stocks are trading at a premium that is simply unsustainable. The ECB rate verdict - and more likely Mario Draghi's press conference - could serve up some additional direction ahead of the open. The European economy is certainly struggling and consumers need some impetus to get out there and spend what money they have. Failure to acknowledge this could give traders another reason to look for safety. And here's the graph that spooked investors, sending Twitter shares down almost 18% in after-hours trading. Along with new cars (see 9.17am), Britons continue to flock towards another perennial favourite, housing stock. Southern Europe was particularly tough - organic revenues shrank 14% in Spain and over 16% in Italy. Chief executive Vittorio Colao warned: "The environment in Europe remains challenging and we have continued to experience intense macroeconomic, regulatory and competitive pressures in the quarter." Analysts believe last year's jump in demand was due, in part, to easy credit terms and the windfall from PPI mis-selling payments. Deals where customers drive away a new car but don't actually own it are also popular at the moment -- helping to push sales up. The SMMT reported: 2013 confidence continues into January: 154,562 new cars registered, up 7.6%. Buyers attracted by fuel efficiency; typical new car 27% more efficient than seven-year-old model. Alternatively-fuelled vehicle registrations increase 25% over January 2013. 2014 set for more moderate growth than 2013. Kit Juckes, Société Générale's foreign exchange strategist, doesn't expect the ECB to cut borrowing costs today, although others in the City suggest an unusual 0.15% cut to the headline refinancing rate. He predicts more talk than action today: Against a backdrop of very low inflation and a lack of any credit growth at all, there is every reason to ease further. Sadly, absent deflation and in the face of improving economic data, procrastination and token easing are more likely than real action. We look for no move, while there is a significant minority in the market expecting a further 15bp shift down in the Refi to 0.1%. Most economists expect more half-promises of further action the press conference and more easing in the months ahead. The euro is flat against the US dollar this morning, bobbing around the $1.352 mark. European stock markets have risen in early trading, but there's a sense of caution as traders wait for the ECB's announcement at 12.45pm GMT, and then Mario Draghi's press conference 45 minutes later. The main indices are all positive, although the FTSE 100 is up just 11 points. It is being dragged back by AstraZeneca (-3%), which warned investors that the loss of lucrative patents on high-margin medicines will hit sales and profits this year. Generic rivals to its Nexium drug (for heartburn and ulcers) should hit the markets in May. There's better jobs news in the UK this morning -- Derby's Bombardier train making plant has won the £1bn contract to supply rolling stock to Crossrail (an ambitious project to link areas east and west of London with a train line running under the capital). The only train building factory in Britain fought off competition from Japan's Hitachi and CAF of Spain to supply 65 trains for the line. It had warned that its factory in Derby, which employs 1,500 people, could have closed if it hadn't won the Crossrail contract (just to clarify, Bombardier are a Canadian firm, but with UK operations) More here: Bombardier UK wins £1bn Crossrail contract Thousands of jobs are also going at Volvo as the truck maker tries to boost its own profitability. The world's second largest truck maker has more than doubled its layoffs target to 4,400 (including 2,000 redundancies announced last year). The axe will fall on white-collar jobs in truck-making divisions, along with sales, marketing, IT, HR and finance roles. The blow was announced as Volvo reported a 37% drop in profits in the last three months of 2013. Sales had picked up in the US, but it saw a slowdown in Europe as new emission rules kicked in. Earlier this morning, Sony confirmed rumours that it will spin off its computing and television operations -- and also hit its workforce with the news that 5,000 jobs will be cut. Reuters has more details. The news was prompted by falling demand for PCs, leading to squeezed profits -- apparently manufacturers make just $15 of operating profit per computer. Sony's latest results, also announced this morning, confirmed that profitability is a challenge - it now expects to lose 110 billion yen (around £665m) this year, not the 30 billion yen profit it was aiming for. Today's ECB meeting is particularly enticing as economists really aren't sure what Mario Draghi and the rest of the governing council will decide today. Dubbing Draghi the "Master of Suspense", Bloomberg points out that ECB has wrong-footed many investors in the past (few expected November's rate cut). As Nick Kounis, head of macro research at ABN Amro Bank NV in Amsterdam, put it: There is a powerful case for the central bank to do more, and there’s a high chance they will ease policy somehow. That may not be through a rate cut. Credit Agricole's economist Frederik Ducrozet is also rubbing his hands, although he reckons policy changes will come next month. Analysts at Commerzbank reckon that a rate cut will come soon enough, even if not today: We are still convinced that, on a medium-term perspective, core inflation will turn out much lower than the ECB currently assumes. As a result, the central bank is likely to eventually cut its key rate once more. And CNN has pulled together 3 reasons European Central Bank may cut rates: The risk of deflation -- with prices rising at just 0.7% annually in January Shaky growth outlook -- Europe may be recovering, but recent turbulence in emerging markets and some disappointing US and Chinese data have Market volatility -- Recent investor nervousness has been felt by Europe's banks, pushing up the overnight interbank interest rate Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business. Central bank meetings dominate the agenda today. The European Central Bank's governing council are meeting in Frankfurt to discuss the state of the eurozone economy, and the Bank of England's MPC corralling in the depths of Threadneedle Street to set UK monetary policy. And there's speculation that Mario Draghi could - or at least should - produce a rabbit from his presidential hat, in response to the deflationary pressures and weak growth stalking the euro area. A cut in headline borrowing costs isn't out of the question, although it's not clear whether it would really address Europe's problems. Another option would be to start charging banks who leave funds with the ECB, imposing negative interest rates on them in a bid to drive more credit into the system. Another option is to end the process "sterilising" the bond purchases which the ECB made earlier in the crisis -- basically deciding to stop taking money out of the system to balance the funds which it had put in. That would create an infusion of liquidity, and there have been signals this week that Germany's Bundesbank would support the idea. If that's all too dramatic for the ECB today, Draghi could make some dovish noises about easing policy in future. At Davos last week he (re)floated the idea of securitising loans to small European firms (bundling them together into new securities). Perhaps we'll hear more about that, at 1.30pm GMT. The Bank of England is unlikely to provide any drama, given its existing forward guidance that the jobs market isn't strong enough to support an interest rate rise. But there's always the chance that it might release a statement.... Ahead of these meetings, we're expecting Europe's stock markets to bounce back after recent losses. Asia 's bourses have been calmer, with the Australian market rallying 1.2% and the South Korean index up 1%. Europe could follow: And there's plenty of important corporate news around this morning, including big job losses at Sony and Volvo (of which more in a moment....)

webTitle: Change to UK's money system could solve our long-term economic problems

fields.standfirst: If electronic money was created directly by the Bank of England progress would be made, but sparks would inevitably fly
fields.body:
Exactly 170 years ago, the UK government passed a law to deal with a banking crisis that was uncannily similar to the one we've just endured. Updating that law may hold the key to preventing the crisis from happening again.

The Bank Charter Act 1844 prohibited anyone other than the Bank of England from printing paper money. Before it was passed, high street banks had been handing out pieces of paper as receipts for the metal coins that people deposited with them. Over time, the paper receipts became accepted as being as good as the coins, and were used as though they were money. Borrowers would sign loan agreements and accept a piece of paper with the bank's name on it, rather than asking for coins issued by the Royal Mint. In a stroke of luck, bankers had acquired the power to literally print money.

Naturally, banks found it hard to resist the temptation to make more loans by simply printing more paper money. The credit bubble that resulted – and the subsequent bust – prompted the government to prohibit banks from creating money in the form of paper notes.

But the 1844 law was never updated to apply to electronic money and still only applies to paper notes. Metal coins and paper notes now make up just 3% of all the money in the UK. The remaining 97% of money consists of essentially numbers in high street banks' computer systems. Banks create this electronic money through a simple accounting process whenever someone takes out a loan.

In the decade preceding the financial crisis, banks created more than a trillion pounds of new money – and new debt – this way. Of this new money, 51% went straight into property, artificially inflating house prices, with salaries unable to keep up. A further 32% went into the financial markets, fuelling good times for the City but storing up problems for the future. Just 8% went to the non-financial businesses that create jobs and employment, and a further 8% went on personal loans and credit cards.

Now imagine if we updated the laws so that banks were prohibited from creating both paper and electronic money. Instead, electronic money could be created directly by the Bank of England and added to the central government's bank account. The government would then put that money into the real economy, through government spending or tax rebates.

It could even give everyone their equal share – an idea described as quantitative easing (QE) for the people. Instead of flooding property and financial markets, money created in this way could start its life in the real economy, boosting GDP and employment rather than inflating house prices and household debt burdens.

Some economists will worry about the effects of newly created money on inflation. But they forget that money is currently created every time a new loan is made, by bankers who have no interest in the effect of their lending on inflation. In contrast, the Bank of England would watch inflation and would hold off on creating money if it started to feed through into higher prices.

Government finances would receive a boost, as the Treasury would earn the profit on creating electronic money, instead of only on the creation of bank notes. The profit on the creation of bank notes has raised £16.7bn for the Treasury over the past decade. But by allowing banks to create electronic money, it has lost hundreds of billions of potential revenue – and taxpayers have ended up making up the difference.

These changes could also reduce household debt. In the current system, new money is only created when banks lend. Banks will only lend if someone is willing to go into debt. That is why the government wants to fuel growth by encouraging more household borrowing. But with household debt at its highest level in history, any further increase could lay the foundations for another financial crisis. Only the Bank of England has the ability to create new money without having to wait for someone to go into debt.

Banks would still exist, as providers of current accounts (which would hold money created by the Bank of England, rather than an uncertain IOU from a bank), and as middlemen between savers and borrowers. But they would lose the ability to create new money in the process of lending.

The idea of removing banks from their role as creators of the nation's money will strike many as radical. But it is surely more radical to entrust the same banks that caused the financial crisis to create the money on which the rest of the economy depends.

Ben Dyson is the founder of Positive Money, a research and campaign group for reform of the banking system. He is a co-author of Modernising Money: Why Our Monetary System is Broken and How it Can Be Fixed

webTitle: SuperGroup shifts focus to international expansion

fields.standfirst: Julian Dunkerton, chief executive of fashion firm behind SuperDry brand, says 80% of new space will be overseas
fields.body:
SuperGroup is to open dedicated web-stores in Taiwan and Australia in the next few months and is hoping to do the same in Korea as it shifts focus to international expansion this year.

Julian Dunkerton, the chief executive, said 80% of about 90,000 sq ft of new space the young fashion company plans to open in its new financial year, which begins in April, would be overseas compared with just 20% last year. Germany will top the list after the company bought out its franchise partner and the company wants to buy out more franchise partners this year.

Dunkerton said: "Europe is where we really plan to take control. If we can bring agencies and distributors in house that's the preferred route of growth." However another 15 SuperDry franchise stores are set to open by the end of April, mainly in Europe, alongside as much as 10,000 sq ft of directly owned stores, taking the annual total close to 100,000 sq ft of new space this year.

The plan comes as SuperGroup revealed a slowdown in underlying sales growth to 1.3% in the three months to 26 January compared to 7.8% in the previous quarter as it lapped strong sales in the previous year and cut back on selling discounted stock via eBay. webTitle: Sales of small, fuel-efficient cars jump ahead as consumers seek to cut costs

fields.bodyText: Sales of small, fuel-efficient cars jumped in January as cash-strapped consumers sought to cut the costs of motoring, according to the latest industry sales figures. Hybrid cars that use electric batteries to supplement their petrol engines also showed strong growth as sales across the industry increased 7.6% on a year ago. The Ford Fiesta maintained its four-year dominance over the Focus to retain the accolade as Britain's best-selling car, followed in third place by the Vauxhall Corsa and VW Golf and Polo brands. The largest car in the top 10 was the Nissan Qashqai, which has a reputation for being one of the most fuel efficient in its class. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said January saw a further push by consumers to increase the fuel efficiency of their cars. Mike Hawes, the SMMT's chief executive, said: "As fuel economy is a major consideration for many motorists, ongoing investment by vehicle manufacturers in innovative, fuel-efficient technology is a key factor in the growing demand for new cars. Looking ahead, the UK automotive industry expects to see moderate, sustainable growth in 2014." Carmakers sold 154,562 vehicles last month compared with 143,643 a year ago, giving the industry a lift after 2013's bumper sales. This was a 23rd successive monthly increase and followed an overall increase of 10.8% in 2013 when registrations reached a six-year high of 2,264,737. Hawes noted that alternatively fuelled vehicle registrations, a category which is dominated by hybrid cars, increased 25% over January 2013. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said private new car sales led the way, rising 17% year-on-year in January, supported by a combination of rising consumer confidence, a buoyant jobs market, cheap finance deals, and motorists' desire to buy more fuel efficient cars given relatively high petrol prices. He said: "The motor industry will be hoping that recent robust UK economic activity is sustained and extended, and that this underpins consumer and business confidence, and their willingness to splash out on new cars. "Car manufacturers and garages will certainly be very pleased to see that consumer confidence jumped to a 76-month high in January, with consumers' opinion of the climate for making major purchases rose sharply in January to be at its highest level since December 2010. In addition, markedly rising employment is supportive to car sales. But he added a cautionary note, saying consumers were still strapped for cash while wage rises remained below inflation. "The squeeze on consumers' purchasing power has so far only eased modestly as, while consumer price inflation has come down, earnings growth is yet to see any meaningful pickup," he said.

fields.standfirst: Drugmaker says it expects sales to be down again in 2014 following the expiry of a number of patents last year
fields.body:
AstraZeneca expects its revenues to keep falling this year after loss of income from expiring patents sent the drug company's sales down in 2013.

The company forecast that group sales this year would drop by a low-to-mid single digit percentage figure. Its earnings per share are likely to fall by a percentage "in the teens".

Revenue for the year to the end of December fell 8%, including currency movements, to $25.7bn (£15.8bn). Operating profit halved to $3.71bn after AstraZeneca made a series of acquisitions to boost its pipeline of new drugs.

AstraZeneca's shares fell by more than 2% to £37.95½ on the company's outlook for 2014.

Pascal Soriot, AstraZeneca's chief executive, said: "As far as we are concerned there is no change in our expectations or our understanding of what 2014 can deliver."

Soriot is investing in research and development to come up with new drugs but has said it could take years before his plan pays off. He said City analysts' expectations for "a couple of products" could have become more optimistic than the company's own forecasts.

Soriot added: "As expected, our financial performance for 2013 reflects the ongoing impact from the loss of exclusivity for several key brands. In the near term these headwinds will remain challenging. However, I am confident that we can return to growth faster than anticipated and expect our 2017 revenues will be broadly in line with 2013."

Soriot reinforced comments made last month that the company would turn round faster than investors expected. Britain's second-biggest drugmaker has been hit by generic competition for its antipsychotic drug Seroquel. Cheap copycat versions of its heartburn and ulcer drug Nexium will eat into US profits from May.

In addition, AstraZeneca's top-selling product Crestor, which treats high cholesterol, will face US competition from cheaper copycat versions in 2016.

AstraZeneca is continuing to spend on priority treatments such as for diabetes, where it was strengthened in December by a $4bn deal to take full control of its alliance with Bristol-Myers Squibb.

The company is also pinning hopes on its new heart drug Brilinta, which has got off to a slow start. Doubts increased over the treatment's prospects after US authorities launched an inquiry into a clinical trial used to win marketing approval. The group has 11 programmes for new drugs in late-stage Phase 3 testing, almost double the number a year ago, and 19 that could start late-stage Phase 3 trials this year or next.

webTitle: Outgoing Ocado co-founder Jason Gissing sells £15m worth of shares

fields.standfirst: Former banker, who launched Ocado with two ex-Goldman Sachs colleagues, still owns 2.56% of online grocer
fields.body:
Departing Ocado co-founder Jason Gissing sold more than £15m of shares in the online grocer on the day his decision to leave was announced.

In a statement to the stock exchange, Ocado said Gissing cashed in 3.05m shares at 498.75p on 4 February, when Ocado's annual results were released. The £15.2m sale leaves Gissing with 14.94m shares in Ocado, or 2.56% of the company. His remaining stake is worth about £79m.

Ocado said on the day of the share sale that Gissing, its commercial director, would leave the company in May after 14 years. The former investment banker launched Ocado with two former colleagues from Goldman Sachs in 2000.

After serving as finance director for 10 years, Gissing has been less involved with the operation of the business in recent years. He is getting no payoff for quitting in order to spend more time with his four children and work on social and environmental projects.

A spokeswoman for Ocado said the sale was made by a blind trust that holds about half of Gissing's Ocado stake, and that he did not make the decision.

Ocado's stock price fell on the day Gissing sold his shares after its annual loss widened, despite signing a ground-breaking deal in 2013 to run Morrisons' new online operation.

The company's shares have had a turbulent time since they debuted on the stock market at 180p in 2010. They hit a record high of 541p on 13 January.

Ocado shares were up 1.7% at 535.5p in early afternoon trading.

fields.standfirst: But group predicts revenues will begin to recover as 4G brings more customers to its networks
fields.body:
Vodafone has reported a near 10% fall in European revenues as recession continues to bite, but the group predicted revenues will begin to recover as 4G brings more customers to its networks, and the impact of price cuts imposed by regulators begins to ease.

The superfast mobile internet service is now live in 13 British cities, with 370,000 customers signed up so far. In the UK, Vodafone added a net 191,000 contract customers in the December quarter, but revenues fell 5% due to competition and regulatory price cuts.

"The environment in Europe remains challenging and we have continued to experience intense macroeconomic, regulatory and competitive pressures in the quarter," said chief executive Vittorio Colao. "The shift to 4G is gaining momentum and we have seen improving mobile customer net addition trends. We are therefore optimistic that our revenue performance will begin to improve as regulatory headwinds ease and customer appetite for video and content services increases."

Vodafone now has 2 million 4G customers across 13 countries, and has committed £7bn of the £130bn from the sale of its American subsidiary Verizon Wireless to Project Spring. This will expand the speed and coverage of its mobile internet services across Europe and boost the number of retail outlets in Britain.

At group level, revenues fell nearly 5% to £9.856bn, a shade lower than City forecasts, and not enough to stop the shares rallying 2.5% to 221p.

Performance in Europe was twice as bad as in the September quarter, when revenues fell 5%. Germany, which is Vodafone's largest market in the region, fell 8%, a steeper decline than last quarter. Spain (-14%) and Italy (-17%) remained extremely weak.

Asia, the Middle East and Africa offset falls elsewhere, growing 5.5%, and mobile internet in India is booming, with subscribers up 38% in the quarter to nearly 46 million. However, the soaraway growth seen in Turkey over recent years has begun to subside, with 4% growth replacing the double-digit performances of previous quarters.

webTitle: Paying GST on education would be an unpopular but progressive move

fields.standfirst: Exempting education from the GST is costing the government $3.3bn and doing nothing to stop the rising cost of school fees
fields.body:
The start of every school year involves a fair bit of trepidation for parents of those children starting their first year of school. And while they drop off their kids and wave goodbye at the classroom door, the parents might also feel some trepidation when they think about the costs to be paid over the following 13 years.

Thanks to the Australian Scholarships Group (ASG), those parents can now have a pretty good idea. And for some, it’s going to be a fair lump of money.

The figures released by the ASG cover the cost of education from preschool through to year 12 in each state in government, Catholic and private (non-Catholic) schools. Not surprisingly, those parents sending their kids to private schools will be expected to pay the most. For children starting preschool this year, the ASG estimates it will cost $367,569 to put them through till the end of secondary school. That figure include fees, extracurricular activities, clothing, necessities and computer and internet access.

For those going through the Catholic system the cost is around half the non-Catholic school cost, coming in at $186,641. Meanwhile, those starting preschool this year at a government school can expect to have cost their parents around $57,455 by the time they get to the stage of wondering whether or not Dad will let them go to schoolies on the Gold Coast (speaking for myself, the answer will be, “no”) .

If $367,000 sounds like a lot of money, the parents of that child starting preschool can at least be thankful they have not just given birth to a child this year. The ASG estimate that by the time a child born in 2014 starts school, it will cost up to $458,995 to attend a private non-Catholic school.

Over the next four years, ASG expects the cost of education to go up by around 25% for private schools, 23% for Catholic schools and 10% for government schools.

While in the non-government schools the biggest increases in costs are expected in the secondary school years, for government schools, the major increase in costs is expected to occur in the preschool year.

This increase in costs is not surprising, for over the past decade education fees have increased almost as greatly as any other household expense. Since 2003, only the price of tobacco as well as electricity, gas, water and sewerage have increased by more than the fees for secondary education. The fees for primary education come in as the eighth biggest price increase, with tertiary education just outside the top 10 in twelfth place.

If we compare various education expenses with other standard family expenses such as health costs, housing prices, rent and childcare, school fees rises have over the past decade generally outstripped them all.

Not surprisingly, the price rises have also varied across the country. However perhaps surprisingly, Perth and not Sydney is the capital city that has experienced the greatest increase in such prices since 2003.

While Sydney ranks second in overall increase in the price of education, most of that can be placed on the increase in the fees of attending tertiary education in Sydney compared to other capital cities. The price of primary education fees in Perth since 2003 have increased a whopping 113%, far outstripping the 83% increase that occurred in Adelaide and Brisbane in that time.

This increase in expense, however, brings with it more than just the question of how to pay for your child’s education. Choosing to send your child to private school remains a choice. No one forces you to outlay over $350,000. But because of the growth in private education over the past decade, and the increase in prices far in excess of overall inflation, education has grown in the level of importance in our annual spending.

In 2000, the ABS’s basket of goods used to calculate inflation had education spending accounting for 2.69% of the average household’s annual spend. By 2005, this had increased slightly to 2.73%; the latest weighting, calculated in 2011, has it up to 3.18%.

While this suggests we are spending more than ever before on education for our children (and ourselves), it also means that less of our money is being spent on items that are covered by the GST.

Increases in the amount we spend on non-GST services – such as education – is the main reason why our tax base is said to be shrinking. In the first few years of the GST it took in just over 16% of all revenue gathered by the government. Now it only accounts for around 14%. That means the government must depend on the less predictable income and company taxes.

And as last week’s release of the 2013-14 tax expenditures showed, the exemption of education fees from the GST cost the government $3.3bn in revenue.

Normally broadening the GST would be a regressive measure, however as is expected, the wealthier households spend more of their income on education than poorer ones.

The ABS found that in 2009-10, while the wealthiest 20% of households spent 2.3% of their annual expenditure on primary and secondary school fees, the poorest 20% spent only 0.35%:

Thus broadening the GST to include education would be a quite progressive measure.

But it would also be deeply unpopular.

Not only would the government have to overcome voters’ usual displeasure with any tax increases, the independent and Catholic schools would go on a warpath not seen since Mark Latham school’s hit list. It would also likely see the wrath of all sides of politics who would claim the tax was an attack on education.

And so we shall continue to see school fees rise well above wages and other prices. As a result we’ll spend more than ever before on education, both personally and no doubt through our taxes. And all the while our tax base will continue to narrow due to that very expense.
